[File: aptos-core/peer-monitoring-service/client/src/peer_states/node_info.rs] [Function: record_node_info_response()] [State inconsistency] Does the two-step process of write().record_response_success() followed by assignment to recorded_node_info_response create a window where the tracker state and actual response are inconsistent, allowing Byzantine peers to trigger incorrect monitoring decisions? [File: aptos-core/peer-monitoring-service/client/src/peer_states/node_info.rs] [Function: handle_request_failure()] [Deadlock] Can concurrent read locks on request_tracker from get_request_tracker() combined with write locks from handle_request_failure() create deadlock scenarios that halt peer monitoring and affect validator liveness? [File: aptos-core/peer-monitoring-service/client/src/peer_states/node_info.rs] [Function: handle_monitoring_service_response()] [Monotonicity violation] Can a Byzantine peer send decreasing highest_synced_version or epoch values that violate blockchain monotonicity invariants, potentially causing monitoring to incorrectly assess peer health or trigger false alarms? [File: aptos-core/peer-monitoring-service/client/src/peer_states/node_info.rs] [Function: handle_monitoring_service_response()] [Version range attack] Can malicious peers provide lowest_available_version > highest_synced_version creating invalid version ranges that could crash downstream consumers or cause state sync failures?
